description: Identifies out-of-distribution risks, adversarial vulnerabilities, and explains potential failure scenarios in unseen data

result.generalization_assessment: The model demonstrates strong generalization within in-distribution scenarios but exhibits limitations when faced with data distributions not well-represented in training. Its performance is typically robust under small perturbations, though vulnerabilities persist at the margins.
ood_risks: Unseen or rare data categories, such as niche dialects, uncommon sensor readings, or medical conditions not present in training.
Domain shifts—e.g., a model trained on news text struggling with social media slang.
adversarial_vulnerabilities: Small input perturbations (e.g. adversarial noise) causing significant prediction changes.
Manipulated inputs crafted to exploit model biases or lack of oversight (e.g., adversarial attacks on image recognition models).
distribution_shift_concerns: Covariate shift between training and deployment environments (e.g., imaging devices with different specifications).
Temporal drift—changes in underlying data patterns over time, such as evolving language or user behaviors.
edge_cases: Inputs at the boundaries of training data, such as maximum or minimum sensor values.
Ambiguous or malformed inputs that do not conform to expected structure.
failure_scenarios: Catastrophic misclassification when multiple OOD features co-occur in a single instance.
Critical errors when encountering adversarially crafted inputs in safety-critical applications.
brittleness_factors: Limited ability to extrapolate outside observed data ranges.
Sensitivity to minor, semantically irrelevant changes in input.
recommendations: Enhance OOD detection and rejection mechanisms prior to downstream usage.
Incorporate adversarial training and regularization to improve robustness.
Diversify and augment training data to better reflect target deployment environments.
Perform ongoing monitoring for distribution shift, with mechanisms for human intervention.
Deploy with conservative fallback policies for high-risk or ambiguous predictions.
